entry.title: SAC: issue with new builder experience in story design
entry.content:
hello all!

after update Q3-2025 in early release tenant, we tried to create some stories with the new builder experience. we found out that when creating a story through chrome browser we cannot add a filter in the story and we get the error:

 

[FailedAction - Action: store.createInstance@[{"app":"MAIN_APPLICATION"},{"story":"storyID"},{"table2":"92680339-4178-4606-9781-276892589378"},{"memberSelectorDialog":"MemberSelectorDialog"}] - Error: Store.CanNotRecreateInstance/Cannot create [{"app":"MAIN_APPLICATION"},{"story":"storyID"},{"table2":"92680339-4178-4606-9781-276892589378"},{"memberSelectorDialog":"MemberSelectorDialog"}], instance already exists.]
Correlation ID: 3109125650744680b648262069645231
 
if we create the same story through edge browser this error does not occur. 
Is it something new? should we use only edge from now on?
thanks
thomas

entry.title: SAP Analytic Cloud has really limited functionalities. Am I using it correctly?
entry.content:
Hey gurus,
supposedly this is SAP's product to compete against tableau or power bi

  • Linked dimension has to be in the graph or widget not working, so it's extremely limited compared to power pivot which can be sliced however you want as long as there's a linked dimension.

For example if i have a table with sales and customer ID and another table with customer ID and customer region. Power pivot can easily do a graph of sales by customer region as long as customer ID fields are linked. Whereas in SAC, the linked dimension which is the customer ID has to stay in the graph or it renders error. but what's the point of linked dimension havng to be in the graph to make it work? the whole point of linking to me is establishing relationship so that I can explor the data in differe ways.

  • No good way to do calculations easily, eg if sales is a measure, it doesn‚Äôt seem possible to do counts/sum/avg at the same time or to do filtering by criteria(sales > 100$). If it‚Äôs dimension, sum is not possible. The dimension to measure function can only do count/avg.
  • Data models not working in stories only working if I go to data analyzer and do ad hoc.

entry.title: How to Migrate from Standalone SAP Analytics Cloud tenant to the SAC component in SAP Business Data
entry.content:
Are you moving from a standalone SAC tenant to the SAC component within SAP BDC? Here's what you need to know üëá

‚úÖ Option 1: Export & Import via SAC Content Network (Quick but Limited)

Yes, you can export and import SAC objects (stories, models, data actions) between tenants ‚Äî even from standalone SAC to SAC component of BDC ‚Äî using the Content Network.

But here‚Äôs the catch üëá üõë This method doesn‚Äôt unlock the full power of BDC ‚Äî you miss out on Access to BDC Data Products, Seamless Planning, and AI/ML integration via Databricks or AI Core.

‚úÖ Option 2: Recommended ‚Äì Rebuild with BDC in Mind

SAC ObjectMigration Strategy

üìä Stories & Dashboards :: Export/import via Content Network ‚Üí Repoint to BDC-backed models. Rebuild if needed.

üìà Planning / Analytic Models :: Recreate in Datasphere component of BDC‚Üí Connect to SAC for visualization

üîÅ Data Actions :: Rebuild manually in SAC component of BDC

üîå Connections :: Must be recreated in BDC

üîÑ Seamless Planning :: Set up SAC integration with Datasphere ‚Üí avoid data duplication

üß† Think of it as: Lift, Evaluate, Rebuild Smartly

You're not just copying. You're migrating to a better foundation and following are some of the advantages with option 2:

 

  • ‚úÖ BDC Data Products = reusable, governed assets
  • üîó Seamless Planning = real-time integration, no more data copies
  • ü§ñ AI/ML Capabilities = unlock smart forecasting, predictive planning
  • üß© Business Data Fabric = unified, scalable architecture

 

üìå Tip: Treat this as an opportunity to rethink your models, optimize performance, and align with SAP's future-ready data strategy.

#SAPBDC #SAPAnalyticsCloud #SAPDatasphere #SeamlessPlanning #SAPMigration #AIinSAP #BusinessDataCloud

entry.title: Binding a SAC Custom Widget to Multiple Models Simultaneously
entry.content:
EDIT: I have created an improvement request for this feature. If you're interested in it please vote here: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/352949

Is it possible to connect a custom widget to more than one model at the same time? I'm developing a custom widget that compares data across models, and it would be highly beneficial to retrieve data directly from these models. Currently, I've implemented a workaround by passing data from hidden tables, each connected to a separate model.

According to the announcement post from 2022:

The keys of the dataBindings property represent the arbitrary name of the dataBinding, and contains a "feeds" property which is an array of objects that define a "feed". Currently this is limited to defining one dataBinding object. Defining multiples will not yield any error but only the first one will be used.

As far as I can tell, this limitation still applies. Are there any plans to support multiple dataBindings in the future?

Cheers,
≈Åukasz

entry.title: SAC Story viewers are unable to change Input control values
entry.content:
Hello,
I noticed that in a SAC story (Optimized design mode) with an Input control page filter on a dimension, viewers are unable to see values other than the ones set in the edit mode.
In the edit mode, I have selected a couple of values as default and and ensured that the check box "Allow viewers to modify selections" is enabled. 
In view mode, users can only select/deselect the initial  selected values ( even after selecting "show inactive values" ). I would have expected they should be able to see all possible values and select/deselect as required. Is my understanding incorrect?

entry.title: How can i show a total amount of full year in the story when story has date story filter(YYYY/MM).
entry.content:
The model that i used to SAC story, is planning model with Account dimension.

and the goal is, i will receive the date as a dimension filter(YYYYMM/flat presentation) and show the total value of the year with fixed version like AOP.

ex) when 202503 is entered, i want to show total value 200,000.


202501 - 67,000
202502 - 10,000
202503 - 56,000
.
.
.
202512 - 67,000

-----------------------------------------
=> 200,000

To achieve this, i used the lookup formula in the calculated measure,

but when i use Current("Year") for the Date condition as [LOOKUP([Amount] ,[d/Version]="public.AOP" and [d/Date]=Current("Year" ))] the cell value does not come out(below image).

 



If there is a way to do it, please share it.
Thank you.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud for planning - Improve Advanced Formula for Date
entry.content:
Hi friends,

I'am using following Advanced formula. Does someone has a better and more slim way to express this:

DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(2,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(3,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(4,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(5,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(6,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(7,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(8,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(9,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(10,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(11,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(12,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)

Thanks in advance.

Kind regards,

Ismail

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud - SUM of Subtotals is not matching the Total
entry.content:
Hi all,

I'm building a dashboard in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) using a live connection to an SAP HANA view. I have an issue that when results are presented for multiple Org Units the SUM of the Subtotals (for each Org Unit) is not matching the overall Totals (for all Org Units). 

The underlying data model contains daily records that could be simplified into these fields:

  • Date (attribute)
  • FTE (measure ‚Äì stable over time)
  • Quota (measure ‚Äì may change daily)
  • Org Unit (attribute with hierarchy)

If an Org. Unit doesn't have a Quota value for a specific day, there is no record at all for that day and the row is missing (not NULL or 0).

In SAC model I have added date hierarchy (Year-Quarter-Month) based on the Date field and created a calculated measure TotalFTE = FTE * Quota to display the TotalFTE month by month on the dashboard.

However, when aggregating TotalFTE by Org Unit at the daily level, I found that Org Units with incomplete daily records had inconsistent results as their denominator was not matching denominator of Org Units with complete daily records.

For example:

  • If Org Unit A had had records for only 15 days in a 30-day month the denominator was 15: TotalFTE(Subtotal A) = FTE*Quota/15.
  • Org. Unit B with complete records for the whole month (30 days) had the denominator as 30: TotalFTE(Subtotal B)=FTE*Quota/30.

This then resulted that the SUM of Subtotals (Subtotal A + Subtotal B) were not matching the Totals: TotalFTE(A+B)=FTE(A+B)*Quota(A+B)/30, as the denominators were not the same.

When trying to fix this, I enhanced the HANA view to include:

  • A Month column (derived from Date)
  • A CountMonthDays field (the number of calendar days in each month, e.g. 31 for March)

I then updated the SAC formula to normalize against the number of days in the month: TotalFTE = FTE * Quota / CountMonthDays to have the same denominator.

This worked well at the monthly level ‚Äî Subtotals and Totals aligned correctly.

However, the problem reappears when:

  • Aggregating by Quarter or Year
  • Users apply filters for custom time ranges (e.g. Jan‚ÄìMay)

Since some Org Units don‚Äôt have records for every Month in the selected period, their TotalFTE is divided by fewer days due missing months (e.g. only 90 instead of 151), while the total uses the full range (e.g., 151 days), causing Subtotals ‚â† Totals again.

Thanks in advance for any ideas or experience with this issue!

entry.title: Why are dimension attributes not available in Calculated Dimensions in a SAC Story?
entry.content:
Problem Statement

We are using SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with a live connection to an Analytic Model (AM) created on top of a Fact Table  in SAP Datasphere.

We observed that:

  • When trying to create Calculated Dimensions within the SAC , only keys and columns from the Fact Table are available.
  • Attributes from associated Dimension Tables are not visible for use in formula expressions inside Calculated Dimensions.
  • However, those same attributes can be displayed in SAC stories without issue.

In below example only keys and dimension attributes from FACT are available and not all the attributes from the Dimension tables joined with FACT -

 

Question:

Why are dimension attributes (from Dimension Tables joined with FACT) not available in Calculated Dimensions, even though they appear in the SAC story view?

In my opinion, this behavior is due to the live connection architecture and how SAC interprets model metadata from Datasphere:

  1. SAC only allows calculated logic (e.g., Calculated Dimensions) to reference fields that are part of the Analytic Model schema.

  2. When the AM is built directly on a Fact Table/View, it only includes the foreign keys, not the descriptive attributes of related dimensions.

  3. In a live connection, SAC pushes all calculation logic to Datasphere, so fields must be explicitly present in the underlying dataset or view for them to be available in formulas.

To make dimension attributes available in Calculated Dimensions within SAC, we have used Graphical Views with Explicit Joins

  • In Datasphere, created a Graphical View where we joined the dimension tables to the Fact Table using foreign keys.

  • This exposed both keys and attributes in the resulting Analytic Model, making them available in SAC for both display and calculations.
  • With this approach we can see all the attributes also from Dimension Tables/Views in a Calculated Dimension Formula.

 

 

Is this the correct approach? or is there alternative approach?

Can we avoid using Graphical Views (with explicit joins) and still access all necessary attributes for calculated logic?
